title: 111_hr6286
content: The "Free Speech and Citizen Fairness Act of 2010" repeals the annual aggregate limit on contributions by individuals and limitations on coordinated expenditures by political parties. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to remove limitations on contributions and coordinated expenditures. Blogger protection is also included in the legislation. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to exempt uncompensated individual internet activities from being treated as contributions or expenditures. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to exempt internet activities from being treated as contributions or expenditures, with specific exceptions for certain payments related to email lists and public communications. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to exempt internet activities from being treated as contributions or expenditures, with specific exceptions for certain payments related to email lists and public communications. Additionally, any uncompensated personal services or use of equipment for internet activities by individuals or corporations primarily engaged in internet activities are excluded, except for specific payments. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to exempt internet activities from being treated as contributions or expenditures, with specific exceptions for certain payments related to email lists and public communications. Internet activity is defined to include various online communication methods. Blogs and other internet publications are covered under the general media exemption. Publications under general media exemption are amended to include any Internet or electronic publication, such as blogs, under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. The amendments made by this Act will apply to expenditures and disbursements made from 2010 onwards.
